questions.explanation: Managing directors and even board of directors' members are, legally, the ones with total responsibility for the organization, its assets, liabilities, and decisions. This does not and cannot change by delegating decisions and authority downward to subordinates.

questions.question: Keeping your information systems safe and secure requires all of the following actions be taken, except one. Which is not required?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Installing security systems that are easy to use, maintain, and monitor
Integrating security systems with effective end-user security training
Using organization wide risk assessments to set priorities for identifying and resolving vulnerabilities in IT systems
Contracting with professional IT security firms to establish, operate, and monitor your information security systems and practices

questions.explanation: Organizations may need outside talent for a variety of reasons, but they are not required to attain cost-effective information security.

questions.question: Nonrepudiation of a message ensures that a message:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Can be attributed to a particular author
Is always sent to the intended recipient
Can be attributed to a particular recipient
Is always received by the intended recipient

questions.explanation: Nonrepudiation means that a subject cannot later deny that they sent a message, took an action, or attempted to take an action. Other forms of information security, such as integrity, address the concerns in the other options.

questions.question: The primary concerns of the information security practitioner are:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: That network and systems access controls prevent any unauthorized access or penetration into the organization's systems
That all security plans, procedures, and policies issued by senior organizational management and leadership are implemented effectively
The security and availability of the hardware, software, communications, and data that make up the IT infrastructure the organization depends on
That all information systems, assets, processes, and data are kept secure, safe, reliable and available, in accordance with the organization's overall risk management posture and plan

questions.explanation: All risks pertaining to the information the organization needs in order to survive and conduct its business are what the information security professional must focus on. That includes all of the other options and more.

questions.question: What term is associated with criticality?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Availability embraces concepts such as maximum allowable outage or time to restore, all based on mission needs; this is what “critical” means.

questions.question: Your boss says that since everything the company does with its information is all in the cloud platforms they use, the company have no need for physical security. How might you best respond?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: That's correct, since the cloud services provider and our ISP handle physical security for their systems and everything using them.
Actually, we still rely on our endpoint devices and our local area networks and connectivity; plus, we still have a lot of paper-based business processes and records that we keep.
That's a good point, and since our office spaces are secured and alarmed by the building's owners and managers, they've provided for the rest.
We could simplify the physical IT security situation even more, or eliminate it as a worry completely, if we shifted over to a bring-your-own-device strategy for everything.

questions.explanation: Endpoint security and noncomputerized information still need physical protection, including paying due care and due diligence to back up, restore, archive, and other needs. No amount of bring-your-own (be it device, cloud, or infrastructure) will make that part of your threat surface go away.

questions.question: Business logic is:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: A set of tasks that must be performed to achieve and objective within cost and schedule constraints
The set of rules and constraints that drive a business to design a process that gets business done correctly and effectively
Software and data used to process transactions and maintain accounts or inventories correctly
The design of processes to achieve an objective within the rules and constraints the business must operate within

questions.explanation: The logic is the set of steps and decisions necessary to achieve the objective; some of those decisions may compare intermediate results with constraints and then branch to alternate steps in the logic to make corrections, for example. The rules and constraints by themselves are not the business logic. Processes (software or people procedures) are not the business logic, but they should accurately and effectively implement that logic.

questions.question: When you compare safety to security for information systems, which of the following statements is correct?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: When information security measures fail to keep critical data available and correct, the resulting system malfunctions could lead to loss of revenue, property damage, injury, or death.
Operating a system in an unsafe manner could be introducing information that further corrupts the system, violating its integrity or leading to it crashing, which violates availability needs.
Keeping a system safe also means “safe from harm,” and thus, means much the same as keeping it secure.
Safe system operation is the responsibility of its designers, builders, and operators; the information security people have no role in that, and thus, safety and security are unrelated concepts.

questions.explanation:
“Safety” for information systems can mean keeping the system causing injury to others or damage to their property—to customers, users, or bystanders. Thus, Option A is most correct.
Option B is true as stated, but it reverses cause and effect and is thus, incorrect.
Option C makes no distinction between safety and security, which is incorrect.
Option D is incorrect in that it tries to separate safety and security when they are in fact related to each other.

questions.question: Which statement about phishing attacks is most correct?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Phishing attacks are rarely successful, and so they pose very low risk to organizations.
Spear phishing attacks are easy to detect with scanners or filters.
You can safely reply to an email you don't recognize and ask to be removed from their mailing list; this is not part of a phishing attack.
Phishing attacks of all kinds are still in use, because they can be effective social engineering tools when trying to do reconnaissance or gain illicit entry into an organization or its systems.

questions.explanation:
Option A is false; even if thousands of phishing emails are sent as part of a low and slow attack, one response can generate exploitable information for the attacker.
Option C is false; in doing so, you confirm that your email address connects to a real (and somewhat under-informed) person. Expect more.
Option B is false; attackers work hard to mimic the style, format, expression, and construction of their phishing emails and continually attempt to spoof email addresses, domain names, and so forth. Tools may filter a lot of such junk email for you, but it won't catch it all.
Option D is most correct.

questions.question: You work with a small start-up company that depends on dynamic collaboration with many outside agencies, companies, and academic organizations, as well as with its potential customers and investors, to turn ideas into products and marketing strategies. These ideas and strategies are the intellectual property of your employer and need to be protected, while at the same time they depend on collaboration to produce in the first place. Which of the following would you recommend be the first that the company invest in and make use of?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: More rigorous access control systems, using multifactor authentication
More secure, compartmented collaboration software suites, tools, and procedures
Better, more focused education and open dialogue with company staff about the risks of too much open collaboration
Better work on our information risk management efforts, to include an information security classification process which our teammates can use effectively

questions.explanation:
Options A and B are incorrect; tempting as they are to the geek in us, they are not the first place that effort needs to be spent.
Option D is a necessary and vital task, but given the dynamics of this organization, it sounds like Option C is the most immediate need. Getting this small group of people totally focused on protecting their own future while collaborating with many others in building that future is going to be key to success; thus, more dialogue (C) can lead to a better, more informed, and effective information risk management and classification approach (D).

questions.question: As an SSCP, which statement bests describes your involvement with physical security?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Little or no involvement; building or facilities management and any security guards should handle this.
You ensure that key systems elements, such as server rooms and wiring closets, are kept locked at all times.
You're only involved with physical security of information assets and systems elements during security audits or penetration testing.
You plan, help implement, review, and assess the physical security of IT systems and information assets, based on your organization's prioritized risk mitigation strategy.

questions.explanation: As an SSCP, all that you do should (moral imperative) be driven by the organization's mission needs, including its risk management and mitigation strategies.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> true of policies?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Policies are what are called “directive” controls.
Policies direct or mandate the behavior of the employees of the organization.
Policies prescribe how an organization manages, protects, and distributes information.
Policies are often a collection of ideas.

questions.explanation: Policies state, assert, or direct required behavior.

questions.question: As part of your organization's IT security team, how would you expect to be involved in changes or updates to the system?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Reviewing every proposed change to the software, hardware, communications, or data
Participating during audits of the configuration management and systems build logs and records
Testing major changes or updates to operating systems or applications
No involvement; the IT staff of developers, testers, and the configuration management technicians should be the only ones involved with systems changes.

questions.explanation:
Most organizations do not need IT security staff involved in reviewing every patch, update, or change being applied to a system; thus, A and C are incorrect.
Option B identifies a key due diligence role that IT security can perform and directly contradicts Option D, which is incorrect.

questions.question: Which of the following is the last step in any change control process?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: The correct order for change control is to plan, assess, decide/direct, implement, test/verify, and notify upon completion. Monitoring throughout, as well as informed user involvement, is vital to informed consent and control.

questions.question: Which of these tasks would be part of managing information assets or IT assets?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Reviewing your IT team's approach to configuration management and control of software, hardware, and data
Letting users decide when and how to perform software updates on endpoint devices they use
Ensuring that all sensitive information, of any kind, is covered by nondisclosure agreements

questions.explanation:
Asset management involves knowing what systems, hardware, software, and other elements are used by the organization and ensuring that they are maintained and changed in authorized and controlled ways. Thus, Option B is most correct.
Option C suggests no management of endpoint software, which is very risky.
Options A and D have nothing to do directly with managing IT or information assets, although they are important elements of an information security posture and program.

questions.question: Does each layer of security need to have preventive, detective, and corrective capabilities?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: No, only the highest-priority vulnerabilities in your threat surface need all three control types.
Yes, because you'll need to be able to detect, isolate, contain, and correct even threats that are not layer dependent.
Yes, but there will be situations in which elements at higher levels of security in your architecture will have to manage, direct, or perform these functions for elements at lower levels.
Yes, but oftentimes, other elements in other layers of your security architecture will need to reach further in, in order to be able to detect, isolate, or correct.

questions.explanation: Risk mitigation by means of countermeasures (to detect, prevent, correct) must be cost-effective; trade-offs will have to be made. When this happens, the “reach” should be from higher levels of security down to detect, prevent, or correct.

questions.question: How should you use CVE data as part of risk assessment?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: It should provide most, if not all, of the vulnerability information you need to implement risk mitigation.
It should be a source of vulnerabilities to check your systems against while you're conducting a more thorough business impact assessment.
It provides good insight as to vulnerabilities that might exist in company-developed IT elements.
Since the vast majority of systems in use are based on Windows, if your business does not use Windows platforms you can probably avoid the expense of investigating CVE for vulnerability information.

questions.explanation:
Option B correctly states that the business impact analysis (BIA) should drive how you assess systems for vulnerabilities and choose to mitigate them, based on business or organizational mission priorities.
Option A is false, as common vulnerabilities and exploits data won't help you find improper configuration settings (such as using default sysadmin passwords) or other procedural weaknesses in your systems' design and use.
Option C is false; “common” does mean common to many users of operating systems or commercial product applications.
Option D is false.

questions.question: Under what circumstances can an information systems security audit be conducted without relying on certified, qualified external auditors?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: There are no such circumstances in which this could be legal or advisable.
As part of informal or in-house efforts to assess risk or identify management challenges
As part of the response to a serious information security incident
As a way to reduce costs and complexity involved in preparing compliance reports

questions.explanation: Informal audits can be great ways to familiarize staff with compliance requirements and controls used by the organization, or to illuminate possible risks or the absence of controls. They should never be used in circumstances involving legal or regulatory compliance concerns, or possible litigation.

questions.question: What might be the most important things that an audit report should communicate to senior management?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Specific details of systems, data, and files audited
Identify missing or out-of-date procedures and documentation
Specific details of errors discovered by the auditors
Recommendations for reducing risks, increasing compliance to required levels, or other recommendations for process and product improvement

questions.explanation: Recommendations as to achieving better audit compliance in the future are most likely inferred, implied, or based on the more detailed evidence addressed by the other options.

questions.question: Which of the following would not be included as part of “hardening”?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Initial information security training for all newly hired employees

questions.explanation: While a well-trained work force with a strongly held security consciousness or culture is vital to safety and security, it takes far more than typical initial orientation training to achieve this. The rest are (or should be) part of normal computer security hygiene measures to the degree required by the risk assessment.

questions.question: Which statement correctly describes the usefulness of CVE data as part of your risk mitigation planning?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: It should provide most, if not all, of the vulnerability information you need to implement risk mitigation.

Since hackers use CVE data to aid in planning their attacks, this should be the first place you look for insight as you do emergency hardening of your IT systems. Once these obvious vulnerabilities have been mitigated, a more complete vulnerability assessment should be done.

It's a great source of information for known systems elements and known vulnerabilities associated with them, but it does nothing for vulnerabilities that haven't been reported yet or for company-developed IT elements.
Since the vast majority of systems in use are based on Windows, if your business does not use Windows platforms you can probably avoid the expense of investigating CVE for vulnerability information.

questions.explanation:
Option B does correctly state the risk that attackers may know more about your systems than you do if you haven't thoroughly checked CVE data as part of your vulnerabilities assessment. But it incorrectly goes on to suggest that you fix those first—they may not relate to your organization's highest-priority impacts as spelled out by the business impact analysis (BIA).
Option A is therefore false.
Option D is also false, since even the most Linux-based of organizations will probably have non-Linux systems elements (such as network components) that CVE could have information about.

questions.question: Audit reports usually contain which of the following sets of sections?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Management responds to the audit report after reading it; findings need to be reported before making recommendations.

questions.question: There are many good reasons why even the smallest business or organizations should worry about configuration management and patch management, including all of the following except:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Uncontrolled and unmanaged “push” updates to operating systems and critical applications can disrupt your business activities.
Your employees can make changes to their endpoints, or to systems they access with those endpoint devices, in ways that can disrupt your business.
Change management, including access control systems, are your first line of defense against attackers.
Change management and control processes can help your users be better informed so that they can do their jobs better.

questions.explanation: User knowledge and awareness of changes is a vital part of change management and control, but it is part of the process, not the goal. The other options all address aspects of risks and vulnerabilities, and the role of change management in reducing those risks.

questions.question: Why are shadow IT systems an issue for information security?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: These are exploits and malware found on the dark web and, as such, must be considered hostile to your organization's goals and objectives. They should be banned from the business and its systems by policy.

Most are written by well-intended users and may be widely used by people in the organization, but quite often they are not subjected to even the most basic software quality assurance measures and are outside of configuration management and control. Hence, they pose potential risks to the IT architecture.
Organizations routinely spend more time double-checking the results of such systems, which is effort that could be spent on other problems.

As long as common vulnerabilities have been addressed (for example, by blocking the use of unsigned macros in Microsoft Office), shadow IT components are no more likely to introduce risks than other IT systems.

questions.explanation:
Option B correctly describes what shadow IT systems are; thus, Option A is false.
Option C demonstrates that in many cases, it cannot be shown that shadow IT systems taken as a whole correctly perform business logic or that they attain the C-I-A levels commensurate with the impacts if they fail.
Option D is false; custom software systems such as these are normally not reported to common vulnerability channels.

questions.question: Does a security awareness program need to be reinforced by policy?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: No, because specific constraints, such as acceptable use, address details necessary for effective security.
Yes, to avoid users from being lulled into complacency and thinking that information security is someone else's job.
Yes, because the policies would carry the constraints and incentives for correct security behavior, while providing directives as to required tasks to perform.
No; policies in general are not related to user training and education.

questions.explanation: Policies are the best vehicle to communicate broad and enduring direction to the organization's workforce or constituents; as such, they should reinforce and be reinforced by education, training, and on the job procedures.

questions.question: Baselines are:
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: Baselines are both the sets of hardware, software, connections, and procedures, and the inventory listings of everything in a baseline and what its current version is.

questions.question: The process of identifying and evaluating risk based on level of importance is referred to as:
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: Risk management includes multiple activities, such as risk assessment. Transference and acceptance are choices about how to deal with risks.

questions.question: What is the most often-overlooked weakness in the way that layered defenses are built and operated?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Integrated, automated systems status, state, and health checks that can validate proper update and patch levels, malware definition files, etc., are installed correctly
Synchronizing the clocks on all devices throughout the organization's systems and networks
Monitoring and analysis of data from all security sensor devices
Having seamless, integrated communications with all elements, at all layers, of the defense, as part of integrated command and control of the total security architecture

questions.explanation: While the other options are vital components of a strong, layered security architecture, without the communications, command, and control ability to integrate it and operate it seamlessly, the systems are still at significant risk.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about information risk management is true?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Risk management is a major investment of time, effort, and money, and should only be done when major changes outside of the organization are happening.
Risk management should be an ongoing, cyclic set of tasks, as part of maintaining constant awareness to a changing business and threat landscape.
Risk management should be no more than an annual review activity, resulting in few actions to perform, for most small to medium-sized organizations.
Risk management, like risk itself, is often best transferred to outside experts.

questions.explanation: The people who own and run a business have ultimate responsibility for success or failure; if they choose to ignore risk by under-managing it, at best, they are gambling on bad things not happening.

questions.question: A security audit is best defined as?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: A covert series of tests designed to test network authentication, hosts, and perimeter security
A technical assessment that measures how well an organization uses security policies and controls to protect its information assets
The use of intrusion detection systems (IDSs) to monitor anomalous traffic on a network segment and logging attempted break-ins
The hardening of systems before deploying them on the corporate network

questions.explanation: Audits in general compare how well you understand, implement, and follow standards, practices, policies, and procedures.

questions.question: In penetration testing, which of the following equates to zero, partial, and full knowledge testing?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: A “black box” test is one in which you know nothing about what's inside the box; you only know what you can learn by watching how it interacts with the outside world. A blind test is the test team having zero (insider) knowledge of the system being pen tested.

questions.question: Security requirements should be considered as what type of requirements?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: With today's greater (and wiser) emphasis on security, nearly every security need can and should be linked to a verifiable, testable aspect or feature of the information architecture and the hardware, software, data, and procedures used with it.

questions.question: The ALE (annualized loss expectancy) calculation is an example of which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: Identify the threat and the corresponding vulnerabilities; if you can, estimate the numbers for frequency of occurrence, single loss exposure, and so forth. If you cannot reasonably estimate, you can characterize as high/medium/low (qualitative analysis). Vulnerability management, not a normal term that we use, would refer to mitigation efforts.

questions.question: Which of the following penetration testing strategies best models what a real attacker might be able to achieve in an attack against an organization's information systems?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: Double-blind testing requires that the bare minimum of senior leadership, IT, and operational managers and staff know of the test, and that test team “attackers” are realistically acting as naive outsiders, to make the test as realistic as possible.

questions.question: Which statement regarding Recovery Point Objective (RPO) and Recovery Time Objective (RTO) is correct?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: RTO is always greater than RPO.
RPO is about data recovery; RTO is about lost time from business activities.
RTO refers to time before the disruption occurs, whereas RPO refers to a time after the disruption's occurrence.
RPO and RTO are always equal periods of time.

questions.explanation: RPO is about how far back in time you fall back to re-accomplish transactions or other data changes; RTO is about how long you can afford to spend in incident response and recovery before lost business or other mission needs become too costly.

questions.question: Your organization is considering adding a series of penetration tests as part of its ongoing security assessments. It's never done penetration testing before. What kind of tests would probably not be the best to start with?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Double-blind testing against live production systems and environments
Full knowledge testing against test and development environments

questions.explanation: Growing your organizational abilities to make good use of penetration testing should (as in all things) start small and work your way up and out. Starting on test and development systems, which are not (normally) externally visible, is prudent.

questions.question: Social engineering attacks still present a threat to organizations and individuals for all of the following reasons, except:
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Most targeted individuals don't see the harm in responding or in answering simple questions posed by the attacker.
Most people believe they are too smart to fall for such obvious ploys, but they do anyway.
Most targeted individuals and organizations have effective tools and procedures to filter out phishing and related scams, so they are now better protected from such attacks.
Most people want to be trusting and helpful.

questions.explanation:
Options A, B, and D all demonstrate the hallmarks of social engineering attacks—they work (and have worked for thousands of years) because people are generally trusting, open, and willing to engage with strangers.
Option C, the correct choice, is unfortunately not true; tools may help filter out some email-based social engineering attacks, but few organizations have truly been able to operate with a “loose lips sink ships” approach and deal openly with customers, clients, and many other outside stakeholders.

questions.question: Which statement about containment and eradication is most correct?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Containment and eradication are separate and distinct tasks; once containment is complete, the incident response team moves on to eradication of the causal agent(s).
Containment and eradication usually involve the same tools and procedures, and so they often are performed simultaneously.
Malware quarantine operations are an example of containment and eradication achieved with the same task.

Containment primarily addresses shutting down connectivity between networks, subnets, systems, and servers. Eradication addresses locating the causal agents (malware, bogus user IDs, etc.) and removing them from each system.

questions.explanation:
Option A is incorrect; containment may occur system by system or host by host as the networks are segmented and isolated, and thus, the eradication specialists can start cleaning systems as they are isolated (or the causal agents on them are contained).
Option B is incorrect, because different tools are needed to disable network connections than you'd use to scan systems for malware, as an example.
Option C is incorrect; malware quarantine is more an example of eradication combined with recovery.
Option D correctly explains isolating systems and then cleaning them.

questions.question: Why is escalation part of the detection and analysis phase of an incident response?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: It will require additional resources, such as IT staff, to begin carrying out the next phases of the response plan, and this would require management approval and action.

Management and leadership need to know that an information security incident may have occurred, and that investigation continues. Depending on the nature of the incident as understood thus, far, management may need to take additional action.
Most organizations are unwilling to delegate authority to an incident response team leader, and thus, need to control every action, in order to exercise due diligence.
This is required by NIST SP 800-61 Rev. 2, and in regulations that apply to the particular business or organization.

questions.explanation:
Option A is incorrect; this may be a consequence of the way that the team's detection, response, and recovery responsibilities are defined and supported, but it's not generally the case.
Option C is incorrect; though this might be true in some organizations, it is not related to due diligence and misstates that concept.
Option D is incorrect; NIST publications provide guidance, while federal regulations can make them obligatory on federal and other government activities, they do not in general dictate what the private sector must do.
Option B is correct; management and leadership may have legal, regulatory, or business reasons for knowing immediately that an incident might have occurred or might be occurring, but they cannot fulfill those obligations if no one on the response team tells them about it.

questions.question: Which statement about precursors and indicators is most correct?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Precursors are events that prepare the way for an attack, such as an intrusion, to take place.
Precursors are the observable signals from an event, which may suggest that an information systems security event may happen later.
Indicators are the observable signals from an event, which may suggest that an information systems security event may happen later.
Indicators are events which are part of an information security incident kill chain; warnings are the observable effects that we can detect, that tell us of the occurrence of the indicator

questions.explanation:
When it comes to incident detection, a precursor is an observable signal or result of an event, which may suggest to us that an event of interest—that is, a security-related event—may happen in the near future. Precursors do not, in themselves, suggest that the incident is currently happening. Thus, A is false.
Option C mistakes indicators for precursors.
Option D confuses events with the observable signals from them—that is, the changes they make to target systems, which we can observe. “Warnings” in this context has no meaning—that is, our intrusion detection system (IDS) or intrusion prevention system (IPS) technologies detect indicators and issue alarms. Thus, B is most correct.

questions.question: What is the first phase of an incident response process once the incident response team has been activated?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: First, identify the most critical potential impact or aspects of the incident, and work to contain and remediate those. The other options happen either before detection, or during all phases of response.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding computer intrusions?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Covert attacks such as a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack harm public opinion of an organization.
Overt attacks are easier to defend against because they can be readily identified.
Network intrusion detection systems (NIDSs) help mitigate computer intrusions by notifying personnel in real time.
Social engineering attacks are less effective than technical attacks.

questions.explanation: DDoSs are not typically done via intrusions. Just because you know the attack is coming or is happening may not make defending against it any easier. Social engineering is a fundamental part of most advanced persistent threat kill chains for one reason; it gains the attacker information and access.

questions.question: Why is effective incident management dependent on a well-written and communicated policy?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Because it gives senior leaders and managers the tools they need to manage the incident responders.
If things go wrong during incident response, such policies can provide proof of prior due care and due diligence.

Personal stress levels can be high during incident response; written, well-understood policy and procedures form a solid base for training, which can contribute to minimizing overreaction or impulsivity.
The absence of such policies, and demonstrated efforts to communicate them to staff, can jeopardize post-incident forensics investigation.

questions.explanation: Proper preparation prevents poor performance, whether before, during, or after an incident.

questions.question: During an incident response, what's the most important set of limitations to keep in mind when searching or scanning systems, storage media, or an incident scene?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Having the right connectivity to those systems or elements
Legal limits regarding search or entry
Having the right tools and procedures to make the search meaningful during the incident response

questions.explanation: Violating legal limits, such as searching a suspected attacker's system, could put you in jeopardy of committing a computer crime yourself!

questions.question: You are a member of your IT department's incident response team, but you are not a trained forensics investigator. Which statement is most correct, regarding how your duties and tasks during or after an incident should consider the chain of custody?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: It has no real effect on your duties or tasks.
It should dictate how thoroughly you make log entries or journal notes about each step you perform.
It only affects your tasks if you have to zeroize, randomize, or cold start and restore a system or its memory.
It limits what you can do without a forensics investigator's approval or help.

questions.explanation: Every action you take, whether on a computer or with papers and other objects at the scene, can change or corrupt evidence. The other options may, by themselves, put you at risk of corrupting evidence.

questions.question: Selecting this type of alternate processing site would be appropriate when an organization needs a low-cost recovery strategy and does not have immediate system recovery requirements:
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: Hot site and mirror site mean the same thing (mirror all ongoing operations, as if in parallel).

questions.question: The type of data backup that only backs up files that have been changed since the last full backup is called?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: Incremental backs up subsets of files regardless of the last update date but works through all files eventually. Partial just does a selected set of files—for example, for one user.

questions.question: This data backup strategy allows data backup to an offsite location via a WAN or Internet connection:
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: Journaling makes note of changes (transactional). Vaulting provides full dataset backup. Other options address storage technologies.

questions.question: Which document documents the steps that should be performed to restore IT functions after a business disruption event?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: The disaster recovery plan (DRP) lays out the step-by-step activation of more detailed response procedures. The other plans provide framework, context, or specific support (communications to public and staff alike).

questions.question: A key escrow service is intended to allow for which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Transfer of private keys between users

questions.explanation: Note that any protocol supporting key escrow is only as secure as the escrow agent is trustworthy. So far, very few such proposals have won widespread trust and confidence in the market, and for good reason.

questions.question: Cryptographic implementation attacks include:
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: Side-channel attacks rely on trying to infer internal behavior of the cryptosystem by externally observable signatures, such as noise or ripple on power lines and timing variations. Probing is a reconnaissance technique against web apps. The others are not related to cryptoattacks.

questions.question: Key clustering represents the significant failure of an algorithm because?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: A single key should not generate different ciphertext from the same plain text, using the same cipher algorithm.
Two different keys should not generate the same ciphertext from the same plain text, using the same cipher algorithm.
Two different keys should not generate different ciphertext from the same plain text, using the same cipher algorithm.
A single key should not generate the same ciphertext from the same plain text, using the same cipher algorithm.

questions.explanation: If this were to happen, it becomes much easier to decrypt ciphertext without knowledge of the original key. The other options show a misunderstanding of how keys map plain text to ciphertext.

questions.question: Stream ciphers are normally selected over block ciphers because of?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: The high degree of strength behind the encryption algorithms
The high degree of speed behind the encryption algorithms
Their ability to use large amounts of padding in encryption functions
Their ability to encrypt large chunks of data at a time

questions.explanation: Stream ciphers are typically used for highly variable length plain-text inputs, such a streaming multimedia, digitized voice, and so forth.

questions.question: The amount of time or effort required to break an encryption algorithm is referred to as the:
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: Computational infeasibility means it's just not practical or possible to invert (logically reverse) some encryption algorithms; hence, they are asymmetric. Key strength is related to key length for a given algorithm. Measure of merit generally means how well suited the chosen algorithm is, all around, to the needs of the users.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> an element of key management?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: The key space is fixed by the choice of algorithm and the size (number of bits) of the key. The other options talk directly to what key management has to accomplish across a user population

questions.question: Which of the following is a major problem associated with cryptography?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: If your keys are not kept secret, you have no security. All else are details of building, using, and managing cryptosystems.

questions.question: Which of these is a characteristic of cryptosystems using symmetric encryption?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Well suited to user selection of keys and seeds

questions.explanation: Key management is difficult to scale to large numbers of users; symmetric algorithms can be broken faster than asymmetric ones can. Thus, all that symmetric has going for it as an approach is its speed (which is why we use it in hybrid systems).

questions.question: Asymmetric key cryptography is used for which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Encryption of data, nonrepudiation, access control
Encryption of data, access control, steganography

questions.explanation: Steganography, so far, has not shown utility or need to use encryption algorithms on top of its watermarking application.

questions.question: Which statement best explains whether cryptography can protect data in use?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Yes, provided asymmetric encryption is used.
Yes, provided that endpoint device security using Mobile Device Management (MDM) systems are installed and working properly.
No, because most use of data, by people or other systems, requires data to be decrypted for use to be meaningful.
No, because homomorphic encryption is not in widespread use as part of the infrastructure.

questions.explanation: MDM approaches to device security help but do not keep data encrypted while it is being used. Choice of algorithm has no bearing on this. And while some analytics processing may be possible on data encrypted homomorphically, actual transaction processing of encrypted data seems unlikely.

questions.question: The correct choice for encrypting the entire original data packet in a tunneled mode for an IPSec solution is?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: The other options don't address encryption of the data packet.

questions.question: Which of the following supports secure transmission of HTTP traffic?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: TLS works at Layer 4 and above, which is where HTTPS operates.

questions.question: A Hashed Message Authentication Code (HMAC) works by?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Adding a non-secret key value to the input function along with the source message
Adding a secret key value to the output function along with the source message
Adding a secret key value to the input function along with the source message
Adding a non-secret key value to the output function along with the source message

questions.explanation: The other options would not improve the integrity of the resulting hash value.

questions.question: What is the process of using a key encrypting key (KEK) to protect session keys called?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: The other options reflect different aspects of key generation, management and recovery, but do not address session key encapsulation (wrapping).

questions.question: Which of the following does a digital signature <italic>not</italic> provide?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: If confidentiality is required, encrypt the content after generating its digital signature.

questions.question: Having a voice conversation over the Internet is referred to as:
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: VoIP is defined as voice over Internet Protocol.

questions.question: How is the data plane used in digital networks?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: It is used to pass control parameters to network devices such as routers, switches, and firewalls.
It separates the flow of user data from the flow of network management information, thus, providing additional security.
It describes how payload data flows between and within network elements.
It is both the circuits and mechanisms by which data flows through the network, and the logical description of data flows within a network.

questions.explanation: The “planes” provide both a logical perspective on networks, as well as very effective circuit-level design and implementation.

questions.question: When comparing Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) and User Datagram Protocol (UDP), which statement is most correct?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: As a connectionless protocol, UDP provides greater reliability than TCP.
As a connectionless protocol, UDP is well suited to multicasting of streaming media.
As a connection protocol, UDP provides greater reliability and error correction.
TCP lacks the ability to handle error detection and retransmission, so is more of a best-efforts protocol.

questions.explanation: Best-efforts basis with no handshake for retransmit request means UDP is connectionless and suited for uses that are tolerant of packet dropout.

questions.question: Where would you find Address Resolution Protocol (ARP) being used?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: ARP resolves IP to MAC addresses at the Data Link layer.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a bus topology?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Each node is connected to a single backbone cable.
Each node is connected to a device such as a switch.
Each node requires a physical connection to a bridge.
Each node is separated using a dividing router.

questions.explanation: A bus does not require any one node to be functioning or to pass information and control along to the next node, unlike a ring.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> an example of data packet switching technologies?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: Peer-to-peer normally applies to services provided by one system to another without a server, thus, at higher than the network layer.

questions.question: Which statement correctly places layers of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) model in the correct order from highest to lowest?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The layers from most abstract to least abstract are Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, and Physical.

questions.question: Most attacks today are happening at which layers of the Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) protocol stack?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The vast majority of attacks focus on web apps, which require protocols above the Transport layer.

questions.question: Which types of networks are not prone to sniffing or eavesdropping?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: Packet sniffing or eavesdropping is not confined to the physical layer. VPNs, with their bulk encryption of routing and payload data, all but exclude packet sniffing type of attacks.

questions.question: A customer wants to keep cost to a minimum and has only ordered a single static IP address from an Internet service provider (ISP). Which of the following must be configured on the router to allow for all the computers to share the same public IP address?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) will also be required, but if the router cannot map addresses and ports WAN-to-LAN, this won't work.

questions.question: Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) and intrusion prevention system (IPSs) use analysis engines to make decisions. Which types of algorithms do many of these analysis engines use?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: “Anomaly detection” suggests detecting something not quite normal, which current analysis engines don't support. Blacklisting is more of an access control or software installation and execution control.

questions.question: Which of the following provides a security benefit of using fiber-optic cabling over any other cabling technology?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: None of the physical media themselves have much of a data remanence vulnerability; the other options do not affect security.

questions.question: Which of the following technologies provides a means to evaluate network traffic flows and, based on a range of configurable rules, alert of possible compromise or rule anomalies?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Terminal Access Controller Access Control System (TACACS)
Network Intrusion Prevention (NIPS)  or  Detection (NIDS) Systems

questions.explanation: None of the other options examine network traffic flows.

questions.question: Which statement highlights the major security benefit when comparing webs of trust with hierarchies of trust?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Individual user decisions in webs of trust provide greater end-user confidence based on reputation.
Hierarchies of trust systems are often implemented with open source solutions, free from vendor bias or manipulation.
Both web and hierarchy systems provide comparable levels of security.
The use of recognized and accepted authorities gives hierarchies of trust greater scalability and trustworthiness over time.

questions.explanation: Certificate revocation (that is, publishing distrust of a user or trust provider) can be problematic in web of trust systems.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a network device that uses context-based access control?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The correct option is C, which involves keeping track of how the client and server move through activities in a session, and looking for the abnormal, using a state table to define allowable transitions.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> a Bluetooth-related attack?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The others involve unsolicited messaging (possibly leading to denial of service), data exfiltration by fraudulent access, and taking remote control of the Bluetooth device.

questions.question: A botnet can be characterized as which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: Group of dispersed, compromised machines controlled remotely for illicit reasons
Group of dispersed machines controlled remotely
Network used solely for internal communications

questions.explanation: Botnets do need networks to run on, and while viruses may be part of the ways that attackers capture (take control) of a system, the tools to take such control are not part of the network of bots (or zombies, as they are also known). By definition, conversion of a system to a zombie or element of a botnet is an attack.

questions.question: One of the most common types of vulnerabilities in web-based applications is related to:
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: Hard coding of encryption or other security control parameters in HTML or other web page source code
Failure to properly validate all input data
Allowing users to run unsigned macros or scripts as part of using the application's features and logic
Inadequately protecting or securing built-in test or diagnostic capabilities in the application itself

questions.explanation: This classic security flaw is completely preventable, if only software developers and their managers enforced lessons learned regarding input data validation.

questions.question: Which of the following social engineering attacks do not attempt to masquerade as legitimate business or social correspondence?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: Scareware attempts to masquerade as warnings from antimalware or other security software.

questions.question: Mobile device management (MDM) solutions are a good way for organizations to manage the requirements for protecting the use of mobile devices in accessing the network and its services. Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> supported by MDM solutions?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: Protection of the pin access to the device

questions.explanation: Ultimately, endpoint security will rely on what the user knows, even if other factors are used as well.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> a standard service model in cloud computing?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: “Private” refers to a single organizational tenant or user of the cloud, while the other options define how that cloud's services will be provisioned, managed and used. Thus, a “cloud” is not a “service.”

questions.question: Which of the following cloud deployment models would be best suited for state and local governments to use with businesses and individuals in their service areas?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: GovCloud is used for highly secure government activities. Community cloud is shared infrastructure, probably raising costs to each sponsoring organization, and potentially adds complexity to delivering public-facing information and services.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about virtualization is correct?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: A Type 2 hypervisor runs directly on the bare metal
Virtualization provides a way to reduce software licensing costs, since only one copy of an operating system or applications platform is needed.
Only a Type 1 hypervisor can support using the same bare-metal processor to host multiple, different operating systems.
Individual virtual machines can communicate with each other via networks, passing files in shared storage areas, but not by direct memory-to-memory transfer of data.

questions.explanation: It's important to appreciate that virtual machines (VMs) need to communicate to what's outside of them, and in doing so, they're as much a part of the threat surface as real central processing units (CPUs) are.

questions.question: Strong authentication requires which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: At least two of the three authentication factors

questions.explanation: The three authentication factors are what the subject has, knows, and is.

questions.question: When implementing a password-based access control solution, what function should be used to help avoid rainbow table collisions?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Salting involves injecting another randomly chosen value into the encryption process used to protect the password plain text.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of the three primary rules in the Biba model?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: A subject cannot request services from an object that has a higher integrity level.
A subject cannot modify an object that has a lower integrity level.
A subject can read an object that has a lower integrity level.
A subject cannot read or modify an object of either a lower or higher integrity level.

questions.explanation: “Read-Up” is restricted in Biba's simple integrity model.

questions.question:
A key employee reports that he left his personal smartphone on a train; he uses it with company systems and data extensively when he travels or commutes. What would you recommend that management do immediately, with respect to identity management and access control, for your federated access systems? Choose the most appropriate statement.
  1. Deprovision the employee's identity.
  2. Use the mobile device management (MDM) system to lock or “brick” the device if it can, and attempt to track its location.
  3. Suspend all access privileges for the employee's identity, and notify all federated systems partners to ensure that they take similar steps.
  4. Suspend all access privileges for devices normally used by the employee, such as their laptop, phablet, or phone (employee-owned, company-provided, or both). If possible, quickly establish a captive portal or quarantine subnet to route access attempts from these devices to.
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation:
Option A unnecessarily removes the identity from your systems and those of other systems in your federated access system; this would not be called for.
Option C still allows devices that the employee had been known to use to access your systems; if the employee, these devices, or both are in hostile hands, this places your systems at risk.
Option B correctly addresses trying to freeze or protect data on the device, and Option D prevents it from being used to attempt access to company systems.

questions.question: Which of the following are behavioral traits in a biometric device?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The other options are not subject to conscious control or action by the subject.

questions.question:
Which statements about authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) in access control are correct?
  1. Accounting provides the authorization to access resources as part of chargeback systems.
  2. Analysis, auditing, and accounting are the services provided by an access control system's server.
  3. Authorization checks to see if an identity has the right(s) to access a resource, whereas authentication validates that the identity is what it claims to be. Accounting tracks everything that is requested, approved, or denied.
  4. Authentication checks to see if an identity has been granted access privileges, using the access control tables in the central repository; authorization validates the identity is allowed to access the system. Accounting keeps track of all requests, approvals, and denials.
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation:
Access control is not involved with resource chargeback—that is, billing; thus, A is not correct.
Option D has confused the roles of authorization and authentication, which Option C states correctly.
Option B is correct—this is the “triple A” of access control.

questions.question: Which step in the identity management process is where privileges are removed?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Privileges may be altered (including being removed) throughout the life cycle of an identity; deletion removes the identity completely from the system.

questions.question: Access to organizational IT systems by remote users needs to address a number of information security concerns. Which of these concerns is addressed by mobile device management (MDM) solutions?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: Encryption of communications and data links to the user's mobile endpoint device
Data loss prevention due to lost or stolen mobile endpoint devices
Physical security of the remote work location, devices, and data used or stored there
Encryption of data while stored on the mobile endpoint device

questions.explanation: MDM systems can lock or randomize content on a device declared as lost or missing. The other issues are handled by other aspects of IT security.

questions.question: Identity and access management is an implementation of access control. Access control can be implemented in one of two broad ways. They are:
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Option A is correct; there is one system and one decision point for all subjects, objects, and rules, or multiple systems for subsets of those. Other options refer to aspects of implementing this broader choice, which can create hybrid approaches.

questions.question: View-based access controls are an example of:
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: A view is a selected set of data items and relationships shown to a user; this limits or constrains the user's ability to learn the presence or values of other items, and thus, is a constrained interface (Option B is correct).

questions.question: Which of the following implementations provides the most rigorous access control possible?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Attribute-based systems use complex logical rule sets (Boolean logic) to check multiple sets of constraints such as roles, time, or other conditions.

questions.question: Due diligence means:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Pay your debts completely, on time
Doing what you have to do to fulfill your responsibilities
Making sure that actions you've taken to fulfill your responsibilities are working correctly and completely
Reading and reviewing the reports from subordinates or from systems monitoring data

questions.explanation:
Options A and B are both examples of due care; due diligence is the verification that all is being done well and properly.
Option D can be an important part of due diligence, but it is missing the potential for follow-up action.

questions.question: Why is the preamble to ISC2's Code of Ethics important to us as SSCPs?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: It is vital to understanding the code because it sets purpose and intention; it's our mission statement as professionals.
It sounds like it ought to be important, but it just states personal values; the canons tell us what to do and why that matters.
It's not that important, since it only provides a context for the canons, which are the real ethical responsibilities that we have.
It sets the priorities for us to address, highest to lowest, starting with the profession, the organization, the people we work for or our customers, and then society as a whole.

questions.explanation:
Option A correctly interprets the words themselves of the preamble.
Option B is incorrect. The preamble does not set personal values (such as “honesty”); these are in the canons and tied to actions we should take.
Option C misses the point of the code.

questions.question: Blacklisting is an example of:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Blacklisting involves eexcluding something based on what it is and is thus, a negative security model.

questions.question: Fred discovers that someone in the company's payroll department has been modifying employee timecard data.If done without proper authorization, this would be what kind of violation?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: The taken-together correctness or wholeness of the data may have been violated, causing some employees to be paid more or less than they deserve. This violates the presumed integrity of the timecard and payroll data. Presumably, payroll staff have legitimate reasons to access the data, and even enter or change it, so it is not a confidentiality violation; since the systems are designed to store such data and make it available for authorized use, privacy has not been violated. Timecard data records have not been removed, so there are no availability issues.

questions.question: Most attacks and compromises are the result of:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Misconfiguration, default passwords, unpatched systems, and basic lack of adequate controls
Failures by management to adequately fund, resource, and manage information systems security measures

questions.explanation: Known vulnerabilities left unmitigated provide the easiest path for attackers to take; this includes obvious social engineering techniques. Many things, including lack of due care and due diligence by management, can contribute to this.

questions.question: Protection of intellectual property (IP) is an example of what kind of information security need?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Disclosure of intellectual property in unauthorized ways can end up giving away any competitive advantage that IP might have had for the business.

questions.question: What is the core objective of an information security program?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: The other options are part of the how and the why, but the organization's purpose and mission are what information security must support.

questions.question: Whitelisting as a security approach:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Requires effective, integrated identity management and access control
Includes what is known to be trustworthy
Excludes what is known to be untrustworthy
Requires digitally signed software or data

questions.explanation: Whitelisting may be implemented via integrated identity management and access control, or rely on digital signatures; it can also be done in other ways.

questions.question: A thunderstorm knocks out the commercial electric power to your company's datacenter, shutting everything down. This impacts which aspect of information security?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: If the equipment cannot run because there is no power, then no data stored in it can be displayed, printed, or shared with users—data is not available. Some transactions may have to be recovered and rerun once the power comes back up and everything is turned on again, but only if transactions were lost completely would there be a data integrity concern.

questions.question: In general, what differentiates phishing from whaling attacks?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Phishing attacks tend to be used to gain access to systems via malware payloads or by getting recipients to disclose information, whereas whaling attacks try to get responsible managers to authorize payments to the attacker's accounts.
Phishing attacks are focused on businesses; whaling attacks are focused on high-worth individuals.
Whaling attacks tend to offer something that ought to sound “too good to be true,” whereas phishing attacks masquerade as routine business activities such as package delivery confirmations.

Whaling attacks send out huge numbers of emails attempting to lure targeted individuals into responding or following a link; phishing attacks use telephone or other means of making personal contact with a selected target.

questions.explanation:
Option A is correct; phishing tends to seek information, whereas whaling (and spear phishing) seeks action, typically the release of funds to the attacker.
Option B is incorrect; whaling is primarily aimed at senior business leaders, whereas phishing can be aimed at anybody, anywhere, if the attacker perceives there is something worthwhile to learn in doing so.
Option C has these reversed; whaling attacks depend on credibility of the business transaction they request.
Option D is incorrect, since it reverses key characteristics of whaling and phishing.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about information security risks is most correct regarding the use of collaborative workspace tools and platforms?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Because these tools encourage open, trusting sharing of information and collaboration on ideas, they cannot be used to securely work with proprietary or sensitive data.
These tools require strong identity management and access control, as part of the infrastructure beneath them, to protect sensitive or proprietary information.
Granting access to such collaboration environments should first be determined by legitimate business need to know and also upon trustworthiness.

First, the organizations collaborating with them should agree on how sensitive data used by or created by the team members must be restricted, protected, or kept safe and secure. Then, the people using the tool need to be fully aware of those restrictions. Without this, the technical risk controls, such as access control systems, can do very little to keep information safe and secure.

questions.explanation:
Option A is false; appropriate administrative and technical controls can and should be used to reduce information security risks to acceptable levels.
Option B is correct in part, but without the users of the tool being fully aware of the CIANA needs pertaining to the data, information, and knowledge that is being collaborated upon, the technical controls are meaningless.
Option C is correct in part but does not address user awareness, education, or training.
Option D covers the key elements of user awareness and education and support the CIANA requirements for this collaboration; thus, the technical controls can do their job more effectively.

questions.question: Which statement best describes how does the separation of duties relate to education and training of end users, managers, and leaders in an organization?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Separation of duties would dictate that general education and awareness training be done by different people than those who provide detailed skills-based training for the proper handling of sensitive information.
Separation of duties should identify groups or teams that have little need for information security awareness, training, and education so that effort can be better focused on ones with greater needs.

Separation of duties should segment the organization into teams focused on their job responsibilities, with clear interfaces to other teams. Effective awareness training and education can help each team, and each team member, see how successfully fulfilling their duties depends on keeping information safe, secure, and reliable.
Separation of duties would dictate that workers outside of one team's span of control or duties have no business need to know what that team works with; education and training would reinforce this.

questions.explanation:
Option A is incorrect; in general, the same core information security team members should actively shape and guide all information security awareness, education, and training efforts across the organization.
Option B is incorrect; it shows a misunderstanding of separation of duties, which typically breaks a task for one trustworthy person or group into two or more sets of tasks for two (or more) trustworthy people or groups, so as to provide a check and balance arrangement. This would typically involve information at the same level of sensitivity or classification.
Option C is correct, as it links the opportunities that separation of duties can suggest for focusing such education and training.
Option D, like Option B, does not apply separation of duties correctly. It is not intended to produce “compartments” that others cannot know about; rather, it drives the design of access controls or administrative controls to prevent one person from taking incorrect action.

questions.question: Your company uses computer-controlled machine tools on the factory floor as part of its assembly line. This morning, you've discovered that somebody erased a key set of machine control parameter files, and the backups you have will need to be updated and verified before you can use them. This may take most of the day to accomplish. What information security attribute is involved here?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Although it is clear that the necessary parameter files are not available, this seems to have been caused because somebody could violate the integrity requirements of those files—deleting them does not seem to have been an authorized change.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the capabilities of camera systems in physical security?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Cameras provide deterrence and corrective capabilities.
Cameras can provide a preventive type of control.
Cameras can be effective without monitoring.
Cameras provide surveillance, incident detection, and response capabilities.

questions.explanation: Remote visual surveillance by itself cannot correct, contain, or respond to an incident. Their obvious or suspected presence can provide some deterrent value, whether or not the attacker can know they are monitored.

questions.question: As a security flaw, buffer overflow is caused by:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Lack of effective scanning or filtering of incoming packets
Failure to configure the presentation layer properly
Poorly designed and poorly tested code

questions.explanation: This classic security flaw is completely preventable, if only software developers and their managers enforced lessons learned regarding input data validation.

questions.question: Source code escrow can be used to protect against:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: The other three options are difficult to impossible to evaluate until its vendor/creator goes out of business.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct in regard to source code escrow?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Allows organizations to meet contractual obligations in regards to software licensing
Allows detection of vulnerabilities in software
Allows backing up of critical software

questions.explanation: Source code escrow can also be applied to reduce the risk of technology obsolescence, such as for device drivers, by paying a licensing (escrow) fee to the vendor.

questions.question: A double blind test is:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: A strategy for operational test and evaluation to see if day-to-day business activities are still working correctly with a new or modified system
A penetration test strategy without the knowledge of the incident response teams

A penetration test strategy in which the test team has no insider knowledge of systems, procedures, or security posture, and the incident response teams have no knowledge of the upcoming or ongoing test
A black box style of testing used during systems development

questions.explanation: Double-blind testing requires that the bare minimum of senior leadership, IT, and operational managers and staff know of the test, and that test team “attackers” are realistically acting as naive outsiders, to make the test as realistic as possible.

questions.question: Every control must be tested to ensure correct operation. Three questions should be addressed by control assessment. Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> a question that addresses this need?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Was the control approved by audit?
Is the control meeting its desired result?

questions.explanation: Audits neither approve nor disapprove controls; they may assess whether your process for choosing, implementing, using, and monitoring the control meets audit standards, however.

questions.question: Treating risk may include four options. They are avoiding risk, accepting risk, mitigating risk, and ______.
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Transferring involves making someone else responsible for the efforts and costs of recovery if the risk becomes an event. Usually this is done via insurance or other contracts.

questions.question: What are the three broad types of risk mitigation controls or countermeasures?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Types of controls indicate whether people, information technology parameters and settings, or walls, doors, locks, guards, and guns deliver the control or countermeasure effect.

questions.question: What type of standards should be followed when conducting information security audits?
