questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: The organization's business plan, business impact analysis, and risk management plan
Standards appropriate to the type and purpose of the audit

questions.explanation: Audits may be done for many purposes; the right standard should be used to ensure that audit procedures, activity, and the auditors themselves produce audit findings that are credible and actionable.

questions.question: Which statement about how different types of controls provide greater information security is <italic>most</italic> correct?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Physical controls provide the greatest security, because they restrict physical movement into protected spaces or actual contact with hardware and systems.
Administrative controls provide the greatest security, since they ensure that all company personnel follow the best procedures to keep information systems safe and secure.
Logical controls provide the greatest security, because these implement management and policy decisions into features and settings in systems software and hardware.
There is no real comparison between these types of controls, since they all address risks very differently.

questions.explanation: Options A, B, and C are all false; the choice of the best risk control for a specific vulnerability in a particular situation must reflect a trade-off of risk, cost, ease of implementation, and residual risk, among other factors. Thus, Option D is correct.

questions.question: Which term refers to disabling unnecessary services, features, and accounts or identities on a system, as a way to reduce its potential attack surface?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls
questions.explanation: Hardening is a subset of all possible mitigation approaches.

questions.question: The proper way to manage and oversee change management in any organization is to:
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Delegate change management and control to the IT or systems departments responsible for particular systems, platforms, or apps.
Require that change requests, implementation plans, and regression tests are reviewed and accepted by all affected elements of the organization.

Adopt appropriate builds and controls technologies that help you control, manage, and track changes to software, hardware, and data configuration items, and establish formal management procedures to have all affected parties participate in such change decisions.
Migrate your business into the cloud via platform as a service, and then delegate all configuration management problems to your cloud services provider via your service level agreement with them.

questions.explanation: Informed management provides better decision making and gains more support from those affected by change.

questions.question: What measures can be taken to reduce the information security risk of shadow IT systems?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: Implement dual-factor authentication and more stringent access controls
Disable or lock features in applications suites that make shadow IT systems easy to write and spread through the organization
Make greater use of Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) data in designing and maintaining such systems
Enforce standards for regular management review of all data produced by such systems before it is used in operational decision making

questions.explanation:
Option D puts the burden of verification and validation on the managers depending on the results of such shadow IT systems, which incentivizes them to better maintain and control their design and use.
Option C is false, as CVE data is for systems and software in widespread use and not for customized one-of-a-kind programs.
Option B is false, because this has proven unworkable in practice and denies the potential of significant payback to the organization if they make better, more well-managed use of these features (and the shadow IT they build using them).
Option A is false, since identity management and access control have nothing to do with homegrown software being vulnerable or prone to exploitation.

questions.question: Why should configuration management should be based on a foundation of policies, standards, and procedures?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: These provide the starting point to make configuration management and control reliable, repeatable, and verifiable, thus, reducing risk.
All organizations work better with written policies and procedures.
Regulatory and legal needs for compliance dictate these.
These form a valuable knowledge base for systems operation and maintenance.

questions.explanation: The goal of configuration management is to reduce risk to systems and processes necessary to achieve organizational objectives. Reliability increases with well-defined, clear procedures and standards.

questions.question: What is the role of users having good security awareness in dealing with the risk of social engineering?
questions.subject: Domain 2: Access Controls

choices.text: By itself, minimal; when coupled with focused task-based or role-based information security training, it can enable employees to better detect potential social engineering attacks, while providing guidance as to how they should respond.
Unlimited; it can inform each employee's reaction to small but not-quite-normal events, as they find the right best way to respond to people and situations.
Minimal; awareness training is typically done when the employee first joins the organization and has little effectiveness without specific job-based training.

Minimal; although it gets users to think about information security as a risk to the company, their jobs, and others, it doesn't help them deal with new or novel situations, contacts by outsiders, and so forth.

questions.explanation: Combining awareness of the constantly evolving threat landscape with practical ways to detect, characterize, and respond to something new is critical to effective defense against social engineering attacks.

questions.question: The business impact analysis (BIA) is considered the most important component of business continuity planning because:
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: It provides the foundation for understanding the criticality of the organization's functions.
It translates the prioritized results of the vulnerability assessment into a risk mitigation plan.
It dictates day-to-day application of risk mitigation controls and countermeasures.
It demonstrates the commitment of senior management and leadership to the information risk mitigation strategy.

questions.explanation: The other options refer to other steps in the overall risk management process; the BIA puts risks in terms of bottom-line impacts to survival or accomplishing prioritized objectives.

questions.question: The third step in risk management is:
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: Framing risk means to state it, in human language, in ways that communicate effectively to decision makers; this is important. Quantify is part of analysis and assessment; thus, frame, analyze, and treat.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Senior management's attitude is not important in risk management.
Risk management must always be conducted in alignment with the goals, mission, and culture of the organization.
External factors should not be a consideration in risk management.
All risk can and should be managed.

questions.explanation: All aspects of risk management require balancing exposure to loss, opportunities to improve, and available resources against goals and objectives. Management and leadership make these decisions, in part based on their tolerance for ambiguity.

questions.question: Who is ultimately accountable for risk management?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis
questions.explanation: Others in the organization have responsibilities for what has been delegated to them, but senior leaders and managers own it all.

questions.question: Determining whether a chosen safeguard is cost-effective means that:
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: You must compare the total expected losses, over time, with the total costs to acquire, install, and use the safeguard.
The single loss expectancy (SLE) is greater than the safeguard value.
The total of replacement costs or values of the asset at risk, other related business losses including lost opportunity costs, is greater than the safeguard value.
The annualized loss expectancy is less than the safeguard value.

questions.explanation: We often simplify risk assessment by using annualized exposure, loss (which reflects fraction of asset value harmed, not total asset value), and safeguard costs; many safeguards have high initial costs and lower annual recurring operational costs. So, the real comparison typically looks across a number of years.

questions.question: It's time for a compliance audit of your security systems and procedures. Your boss wants to save money and have an internal team do the audit. Which statement would be your best response to your boss?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Our internal people may have the right skills and knowledge to do this audit, so this might be a good idea.
We don't really have anyone on our team who understands the audit standards, so we may need an external auditor anyway.
We've got people who could do the audit, but their workloads and our priorities would mean the audit has to be delayed by several months.
Compliance requirements and standards may dictate that the auditors be independent and certified, or the findings may not be acceptable.

questions.explanation: In most cases, compliance audits must be done by trained and certified external auditors if the results are to be acceptable to legal, regulatory, insurance, or financial authorities.

questions.question: SLE = _____ × exposure factor.
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Asset value × annualized rate of occurrence

questions.explanation: Exposure to loss by a single loss expectancy (SLE) considers all assets damaged by the event and the fraction of their value that is lost or compromised.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> true?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: The implementation of a control addresses a vulnerability.
The implementation of effective controls will eliminate all quantified risks.
A control that is proactive and tries to stop something before it happens is often called a safeguard.
A control that is reactive and attempts to limit the effect of an attack is called a countermeasure.

questions.explanation: Some risks cannot be quantified but can still be effectively controlled.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Business continuity planning (BCP) and disaster recovery planning (DRP) are the same.
Both BCP and DRP are mutually exclusive.

questions.explanation: The goal of all of this planning is to stay in business despite risk events large and small. Disasters are large events and thus, a subset of the overall business continuity planning.

questions.question: Why should a security practitioner be alert to identifying single points of failure in systems, processes, or business logic?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: Such points of failure usually indicate poorly performed systems maintenance and upgrades.
Each such point may be a possible opportunity for product or process improvement and is worth investigating.
Single points of failure can bring entire chains of business processes to a halt and thus, represent a potentially critical vulnerability.
During incident investigation, these should be checked to see if one or more of these had become the proximate cause.

questions.explanation: Availability is put at great risk by such single points of failure, regardless of whether they are exploited by accident, other failures, or attackers. Prevention of such impacts should be prioritized and addressed properly.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of testing an intrusion prevention system (IPS)?
questions.subject: Domain 3: Risk Identification, Monitoring and Analysis

choices.text: To verify that the IPS is detecting and initiating an appropriate response to a suspicious activity
To determine whether the IPS is capable of discarding suspect packets
To analyze processor utilization to verify whether hardware upgrades are necessary
To test whether the IPS can log every possible event on the network

questions.explanation: IPSs are not limited to just discarding suspect packets; testing verifies that the IPS you've installed is giving you the right mix of protection at acceptable error levels.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about social engineering attacks is incorrect?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Most targeted individuals don't see the harm in responding or in answering simple questions posed by the attacker.
Most people believe they are too smart to fall for such obvious ploys, but they do anyway.
Most targeted individuals and organizations have effective tools and procedures to filter out phishing and related scams, so they are now better protected from such attacks.
Most people want to be trusting and helpful.

questions.explanation:
Options A, B, and D all demonstrate the hallmarks of social engineering attacks—they work (and have worked for thousands of years) because people are generally trusting, open, and willing to engage with strangers.
Option C, the correct choice, is unfortunately not true; tools may help filter out some email-based social engineering attacks, but few organizations have truly been able to operate with a “loose lips sink ships” approach and deal openly with customers, clients, and many other outside stakeholders.

questions.question: Which statement about the role of end users in detecting information security incidents is correct?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Most end users may have significant experience with the routine operation of the business systems and applications that they use, but they cannot produce useful precursor or indicator information regarding possible information security incidents.

Most end users and their first-level supervisors have the best, most current insight as to the normal business rhythm, flow, and therefore normal loads on the systems and their throughput. They will most likely see anything “abnormal” quickly as a result.
Users think that they know a lot about “business normal,” but we need to rely more heavily on well-instrumented intrusion detection systems, access control, and other monitoring capabilities.
Since most advanced persistent threat (APT) kill chains use low and slow attack methods to reconnoiter and gain access, by the time users see things behaving abnormally, it's too late.

questions.explanation:
Option A is incorrect; it's rather dismissive of the knowledge that most line workers have when it comes to how business actually gets done every day. Users may need better training as to what to do when they think they see a problem, but that's not addressed by this option.
Option C is incorrect, demonstrating a narrow vision that only sees the technological solutions as useful.
Option D is incorrect, notably that it is never too late to sound an alarm.
Option B correctly expresses the value of knowledge and experience. Harnessing this insight in real time as part of an intrusion or anomaly detection process, however, is another story.

questions.question: Which set of plans and procedures should define how the organization makes backups of systems, applications, device settings, databases, and other data for use during the recovery phase of an information systems security incident response?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Information security incident response plans and procedures
Information technology configuration management plans and procedures

questions.explanation:
Option A is false; the response team should need to know only how to find and use such backups and not be responsible for their initial generation or routine update.
Option B is false; the DRP would address options spelled out in the BCP as to alternative processing locations, contingency plans, and so forth, all of which need the backups that the BCP directs be made.
Option D is false; configuration management is the decision process that allows or prevents changes to hardware, software, or key data items or structures, but it doesn't manage backups.
Option C correctly links the purpose of backups—continuing to get business done in the face of accidents, systems failures, attacks, or natural disasters—with the need for a specific set of resources—that is, backups.

questions.question: Creating incident response policies for an organization would be an example of which of the following?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: Note that many IT systems have software controls called “policies,” which should not be confused with documents that tell people what to do and why.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most time-critical phase of activity in incident response?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: The other phases cannot start until you've detected something that might need responding to.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is the most correct in incident response?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: The goal of incident response is to minimize the damage and learn from the incident as to prevent it from happening again.
The goal is to prevent incidents from happening.
Incident response does not require a policy that provides its foundation.
Incident response does not involve problem management.

questions.explanation: Incidents will happen; 100 percent prevention is not a reality we can achieve. Thus, be prepared to detect, contain, and respond. This requires management and leadership commitment and prioritization, which usually requires written policy and direction.

questions.question: You're the only IT person at a small tool and die machine shop, which uses a local area network (LAN) and cloud-hosted platforms to run the business on. The previous IT person had told your boss not to worry about the business being the target of a cyberattack. Which statement best lets you explain the real risks the company might face?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Since we don't handle consumer-level payment cards, and we don't have any proprietary information, we probably don't have to worry about being a target.
We do share an extranet connection with key customers and suppliers, but it should prevent an attack on our systems that could lead to an attack on theirs.
Our cloud systems hosting company provides most of our security, and as long as we keep our systems on the factory floor and the workstations our staff use properly updated, we should be okay.
Since we haven't done even a basic vulnerabilities assessment, we don't know what risks we could be facing. Let's do that much at least, and let that tell us what the next step should be. Soon.

questions.explanation:
Although Option A may be true, it is naive and incorrect; the air-conditioning company that serviced Target stores didn't handle retail (credit card) sales either, yet attackers found it to be an ideal entry into Target's payment processing systems.
Option C is also incorrect; your cloud hosts will protect their systems, and their platforms, from malware attacks from your connections, but attackers who spoof bogus, privileged accounts into your systems can still destroy your business's presence in those cloud systems.
Option B is incorrect; without doing a detailed vulnerability assessment of that architecture, you are at risk making this assumption.
Option D offers the boss a sensible first step.

questions.question: Which of the following would be the first step to be conducted as an investigator arrives at a crime scene?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Prove the integrity of the scene

questions.explanation: Securing the scene limits the opportunity for evidence to be corrupted by other people or processes. It's the first step in the chain of custody.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> a legal or regulatory issue that a computer security incident response team (CSIRT) would have to be concerned with?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery

choices.text: Incidents caused by employee negligence or accident
Incidents caused by misuse of systems by an employee
Incidents that may involve competitors attempting to access company proprietary information
Incidents that disrupt normal business operations

questions.explanation:
Option A usually does not have a legal or regulatory obligation that the CSIRT must respond to (although there may be requirements for the organization to report statistics on such incidents to regulators or other authorities).
Option B could lead to disciplinary actions or firing the employee involved, which could result in litigation.
Option C may be criminal trespass or violation of other criminal laws.
Option D may, depending on the nature of the business and its activities, require safety, security, or investor and consumer protection reporting and notification actions by the organization, regardless of cause.

questions.question: What is the most important component of business continuity planning?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: The BIA sets the priorities that all else follow from.

questions.question: Which concept refers to the point in time to which data could be restored in the event of a business disruption?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: The RTO and MTD express how quickly after an incident that services need to be restored. RPO looks at how far back in time before the incident you have to find and restore data, or re-accomplish transactions and updates.

questions.question: What type of testing that should be performed when initially testing a disaster recovery plan?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: Structured walkthroughs are inexpensive ways to “desk-check” the recovery plan, while beginning to familiarize people with the roles they'll need to perform during an actual recovery.

questions.question: Which RAID level uses block-level striping with parity information distributed across multiple disks?
questions.subject: Domain 4: Incident Response and Recovery
questions.explanation: RAID 0 provides higher throughput but no redundancy. RAID 1 mirrors a whole disk. RAID 4 doesn't exist.

questions.question: Applied against a given block of data, what does a hash function create?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: A chunk of the original block used to ensure its confidentiality
A block of new data used to ensure the original block's confidentiality
A chunk of the original block used to ensure its integrity
A block of new data used to ensure the original block's integrity

questions.explanation: Be careful here; hashing does not change the contents of the original plain text but creates a unique new data block (the hash value) from the original, which can be used to verify the original has not been changed since the hash was generated.

questions.question: In symmetric key cryptography, what should each party use?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Randomly generated value unknown to anyone
Public key exchanged with the message

questions.explanation: A random key value unknown to the recipient will not support decryption. The other options either refer to public/private key systems.

questions.question: Steganography uses cryptographic means to:
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Corrupt the integrity of a message or file in ways not easily detectable
Reduce the likelihood of key clustering
Hide the plain text within another unencrypted data stream, message, or file

questions.explanation: Watermarking is an example of using steganography to achieve a purpose such as nonrepudiation; it is not, however, what steganography is. It won't help with key clustering, and a simple hash of the plain text will show that the plain text has been changed.

questions.question: Symmetric cryptography is best characterized by:
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Using in-band communications for key distribution and management
Using the same key for encryption and decryption
Having much greater work factors than other forms of encryption
Providing for very fast encryption and decryption only in streaming mode

questions.explanation: Symmetric encryption must rely on out-of-band key management; it can be significantly easier to break (lower work factor) than asymmetric approaches for same key length.

questions.question: What is the input that controls the operation of the cryptographic algorithm?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: Cryptovariables tend to specify block size, transposition, or substitution lengths; seeds for random number generators; or salt values. In some cryptosystems, they are fixed by the implementers; in others, they can be user specified.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the Caesar Cipher?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: No transposition is involved.

questions.question: Which of the following is not directly provided as a result of using cryptography?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: Cryptographic support of identity management, access control, file or system integrity checks, and so forth can contribute to availability, but encrypting files or messages without those other security measures alone will not.

questions.question: All of the following address integrity except:
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: Integrity requires a way to verify that message or file plain text has not been altered over time; anything one could conceivably decrypt could lend itself to attacking the plain text's integrity. Encryption, such as DES, may or may not be a part of a chosen integrity implementation.

questions.question: Does the use of asymmetric algorithms have a scalability problem as more people require confidential communications?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Yes, as indicated by the dramatic growth in Internet of Things (IoT) devices becoming part of the Internet.
No, so long as full Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) implementations in IPv6 are used.
No, as long as you're using webs of trust as part of certificate/signature authentication.
No, as long as you're using hierarchies of trust as part of certificate/signature authentication.

questions.explanation: Managing the expiration (or compromise) of certificates is problematic in webs of trust. IPSec doesn't address this.

questions.question: Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) is a block cipher with variable key lengths of?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: This standard was set in 2001 by the U.S. National Institute of Standards and Technologies (NIST).

questions.question: What kind of encryption is used in Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2)?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Data Encryption Standard (DES) in streaming mode
Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) in cipher block chaining (CBC) mode
AES in a combination of cipher block chaining (CBC) and counter (CTR) mode
Public key infrastructure (PKI) using ElGamal and DES

questions.explanation: Set as the standard in 2004 by the Wi-Fi Alliance; the other options are incomplete and incorrect.

questions.question: A certificate authority (CA) provides which benefit to a user?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography

choices.text: Protection of private keys of all users
Validation that a public key is associated with a particular user

questions.explanation: CA authentication of a public key is the bedrock of public key infrastructure (PKI) systems. The other options do not relate to this or misapply public/private key concepts.

questions.question: In its simplest form, how many parties are involved in a transitive trust relationship within a domain?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: For parties A, B, C, if Party B trusts C, and A trusts B, A can infer that C is trustworthy based on B's endorsement or referral.

questions.question: Which of the following algorithms supports asymmetric key cryptography?
questions.subject: Domain 5: Cryptography
questions.explanation: Blowfish and Rijndael are symmetric algorithms; SHA-256 is a hash algorithm.

questions.question: Which statement best compares transmission control protocol (TCP) and user datagram protocol (UDP)?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: UDP is a best-efforts protocol and thus, provides high reliability.
TCP provides retransmission and sequencing control, thus, providing high reliability.
TCP is a best-efforts protocol and thus, provides high reliability.
UDP provides retransmission and sequencing control, thus, providing high reliability.

questions.explanation: Both TCP and UDP are Layer 4 protocols. The difference between them is that TCP is connection-oriented and provides reliable transport services, whereas UDP in connectionless and provides best-effort transport services. The other options reverse the nature of TCP (connection) and UDP (connectionless).

questions.question: How do circuit-switched networks work?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: They divide data into packets and transmit it over a virtual network
They establish a dedicated circuit between endpoints.
They divide data into packets and transmit it over a shared network
They establish an on-demand circuit between endpoints.

questions.explanation: Plain old telephone service (POTS) is the clearest example of a circuit-switched network, with each phone call on a logical connection or circuit for its duration.

questions.question: What ports are commonly used for a Transport Layer Security (TLS) connection?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The ports are defined in Internet Engineering Task Force requests for comments and can be reconfigured/reassigned by systems and network designers to meet specific needs.

questions.question: When establishing connections between hosts, which four identifiers are used to identify the specific connection?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Source URL, source port, destination URL, destination port
Source MAC, source port, destination MAC, destination port
Source IP, source port, destination IP, and destination port

questions.explanation: Host connections are at the network layer and thus, use IP addresses and port numbers.

questions.question: Which of the following are valid host addresses for network address translation (NAT) according to Request for Comments (RFC) 1918?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: RFC 1918 defined private address ranges (pre–Classless Inter-Domain Routing [CIDR]), using host ID sizes of 24, 20, and 16 bits for classes A, B, C, respectively. Count the bits from the left.

questions.question: Which of the following does <italic>not</italic> apply to Secure Sockets Layer (SSL)/Transport Layer Security (TLS)?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Provides secure connections between client and server

questions.explanation: HTTPS or other protocols using SSL or TLS may provide session key wrapping, but SSL/TLS themselves do not.

questions.question: Which of the following would not be a good choice for a secure email system for a typical small business?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Providing end users with suites of encryption tools they can use as they need to, to protect content
Using browser email client plug-ins or extensions
Deploying a private secure email server and configuring encryption services for email as needed

questions.explanation: The other options provide capabilities to set policies to encourage, require, or enforce the use of secure email capabilities.

questions.question: Which statement has the protocol layers in the correct top-to-bottom order?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The layers from most abstract to least abstract are as follows: Application, Presentation, Session, Transport, Network, Data Link, and Physical.

questions.question: What is the biggest security issue associated with the use of a Multiprotocol Label Switching (MPLS) network?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Use of Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) and Data Encryption Standard (DES) algorithms
The need to establish peering relationships to cross Tier 1 carrier boundaries

questions.explanation: Most MPLS implementations provide encryption at higher protocol layers as a way around this. The other options do not apply to MPLS.

questions.question: When setting up firewall rules, which is the best practice to follow?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Allow all and then take away
Allow none and then add specific rules
Use a mix of allow-none and allow-all based on a segmented network and systems view
Use your risk assessment findings to guide this decision for each business process

questions.explanation: This approach forces you to systematically identify required services and connections, and constrain by date, time, or other attributes, one by one. It also precludes overlooking a factory-default connection that you may not need or want.

questions.question: A new installation requires a network in a heavy manufacturing area with substantial amounts of electromagnetic radiation and power fluctuations. Which media is best suited for this environment if little traffic degradation is tolerated?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: Other physical technologies are more prone to electromagnetic interference.

questions.question: Which of the following is typically deployed as a screening proxy for web servers?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: Kernel proxies can help accelerate Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) but do not provide screening of service or resource requests. The other options are not proxies.

questions.question: Which of the following should be part of a network's perimeter defense?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The other options by themselves provide no security capabilities.

questions.question: Which statement best describes what security information and event management systems can do?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Provide script-based management of incident response team actions, to help preserve chain of custody of evidence
Collect data from multiple sources and bring it together for meaningful analysis
Manage network and systems resources, devices, apps, and so forth to ensure policies are consistently enabled and monitored
Provide predictive analytics as a means of identifying event precursors

questions.explanation: The other options take some very smart people to accomplish.

questions.question: A security incident event management (SIEM) service performs which of the following function?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security

choices.text: Configures software for security policies and procedures
Aggregates logs from security devices and application servers looking for suspicious activity
Matches user system authorization with physical access permissions

questions.explanation: Though the other options are useful, if not vital, security tactics, they're not what SIEMs do.

questions.question: Which type of technology can examine network traffic at much deeper levels?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: The others do not allow for application-layer traffic inspection.

questions.question: Which of the following should be used to protect wireless local area network (WLAN) communications?
questions.subject: Domain 6: Network and Communications Security
questions.explanation: WEP and WAP have been shown to be vulnerable; TKIP was a short-lived Band-Aid for WEP and should no longer be used.

questions.question: All of the following are examples of social engineering attacks, except:
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: Ransom attacks (whether by ransomware or not) may involve social engineering as part of gaining access, but they don't use social engineering to implement the attack.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> an example of malware?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: Humans tailgate other humans through checkpoints.

questions.question: What is a type of device with limited local storage capacity known as?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: Thick clients have extensive “local” files, often needing synchronization with servers or cloud backups. Peers, as in peer-to-peer, are part of service relationships.

questions.question: Which of the following should <italic>not</italic> be addressed as part of endpoint security
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: Monitor network traffic across the demilitarized zone (DMZ)

questions.explanation: Endpoints cannot (or should not) have such visibility across all segments of your networks.

questions.question: Which of the following is <italic>not</italic> an essential characteristic of cloud computing?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security
questions.explanation: While one deployment model (private clouds) does support single tenants, that does not make “single tenant” a defining characteristic of cloud computing.

questions.question: Which of the following hypervisor types would be most attractive to an attacker to compromise?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: Type 1, because it runs on hardware and provides lower-layer attack capabilities
Type 2, because it runs on an operating system and therefore provides more opportunities
Neither, because they are almost impossible to compromise
Both Types 1 and 2, since they both exist in all environments

questions.explanation: Attacking the host operating system (or subverting built-in features in it, via illicit access) may provide greater opportunity to attack or subvert the hypervisor.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is the best description of the hypervisor?
questions.subject: Domain 7: Systems and Application Security

choices.text: Allows multiple hosts to share a single operating system
Allows multiple applications to share multiple operating systems
Allows multiple tasks to share a single operating system
Allows multiple operating systems to share a single host

questions.explanation: The other options address other multiprocessing or software deployment strategies not involving virtualization.

questions.question: Greg is the network administrator for a large stadium that hosts many events throughout the course of the year. They equip ushers with handheld scanners to verify tickets. Ushers turn over frequently and are often hired at the last minute. Scanners are handed out to ushers before each event, but different ushers may use different scanners. Scanners are secured in a locked safe when not in use. What network access control approach would be most effective for this scenario?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Device authentication allows the venue to restrict network access to authorized scanners but does not require individual ushers to sign in to the device. This seems an acceptable level of security for this environment, as the scanners are carefully controlled. Moving to any authentication scheme that requires user authentication would be unwieldy.

questions.question: Norma is helping her organization create a specialized network designed for vendors that need to connect to Norma's organization's network to process invoices and upload inventory. This network should be segmented from the rest of the corporate network but have a much higher degree of access than the general public. What type of network is Norma building?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The purpose of an extranet is to allow outside organizations that are business partners to access limited resources on the corporate network. That describes the situation in this scenario, so Norma is building an extranet.

questions.question: Which one of the following is an example of a nondiscretionary access control system?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: A mandatory access control (MAC) scheme is an example of a nondiscretionary approach to access control, as the owner of objects does not have the ability to set permissions on those objects. It is possible for a visitor list or file ACLs to be configured using a nondiscretionary scheme, but these approaches can also be configured as discretionary access control (DAC) implementations.

questions.question: Wanda is configuring device-based authentication for systems on her network. Which one of the following approaches offers the strongest way to authenticate devices?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Digital certificates are the strongest device-based access control mechanism listed in this scenario. Administrators may create certificates for each device and tie them to the physical device. Passwords are easily transferred to other devices and are not as strong an approach. IP addresses are easily changed and should not be used. MAC addresses theoretically identify devices uniquely, but it is possible to alter a MAC address, so they should not be relied upon for authentication.

questions.question: Kaiden is creating an extranet for his organization and is concerned about unauthorized eavesdropping on network communications. Which one of the following technologies can he use to mitigate this risk?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Kaiden should use a virtual private network (VPN) for all remote connections to the extranet. The VPN will encrypt traffic sent over public networks and protect it from eavesdropping.

questions.question:
When Ben lists the files on a Linux system, he sees the set of attributes shown here.
The letters rwx indicate different levels of what?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The permissions granted on files in Linux designate what authorized users can do with those files—read, write, or execute. In the image shown, all users can read, write, and execute index.html, whereas the owner can read, write, and execute example.txt, the group cannot, and everyone can write and execute it.

questions.question: Which one of the following tools is most often used for identification purposes and is not suitable for use as an authenticator?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Usernames are an identification tool. They are not secret, so they are not suitable for use as a password.

questions.question: Gary is preparing to create an account for a new user and assign privileges to the HR database. What two elements of information must Gary verify before granting this access?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Before granting access, Gary should verify that the user has a valid security clearance and a business need to know the information. Gary is performing an authorization task, so he does not need to verify the user's credentials, such as a password or biometric scan.

questions.question:
Ben's organization is adopting biometric authentication for its high-security building's access control system. Use the following chart to answer questions about the organization's adoption of the technology.
Ben's company is considering configuring its systems to work at the level shown by point A on the diagram. To what level is it setting the sensitivity?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The crossover error rate is the point where false acceptance rate and false rejection rate cross over and is a standard assessment used to compare the accuracy of biometric devices.

questions.question:
Ben's organization is adopting biometric authentication for its high-security building's access control system. Use the following chart to answer questions about the organization's adoption of the technology.
At point B, what problem is likely to occur?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: False acceptance will be very high.
False rejection will be very high.
False rejection will be very low.
False acceptance will be very low.

questions.explanation: At point B, the false acceptance rate, or FAR, is quite high, while the false rejection rate, or FRR, is relatively low. This may be acceptable in some circumstances, but in organizations where a false acceptance can cause a major problem, it is likely that they should instead choose a point to the right of point A.

questions.question:
Ben's organization is adopting biometric authentication for its high-security building's access control system. Use the following chart to answer questions about the organization's adoption of the technology.
What should Ben do if the FAR and FRR shown in this diagram does not provide an acceptable performance level for his organization's needs?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: Adjust the sensitivity of the biometric devices.
Assess other biometric systems to compare them.
Adjust the FRR settings in software.

questions.explanation: CER is a standard used to assess biometric devices. If the CER for this device does not fit the needs of the organization, Ben should assess other biometric systems to find one with a lower CER. Sensitivity is already accounted for in CER charts, and moving the CER isn't something Ben can do. FRR is not a setting in software, so Ben can't use that as an option either.

questions.question: When a subject claims an identity, what process is occurring?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The process of a subject claiming or professing an identity is known as <italic>identification</italic>. Authorization verifies the identity of a subject by checking a factor such as a password. Logins typically include both identification and authorization, and token presentation is a type of authentication.

questions.question: Files, databases, computers, programs, processes, devices, and media are all examples of what?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: All of these are objects. Although some of these items can be subjects, files, databases, and storage media can't be. Processes and programs aren't file stores, and of course none of these is a user.

questions.question: MAC models use three types of environments. Which of the following is not a mandatory access control design?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Mandatory access control systems can be hierarchical, where each domain is ordered and related to other domains above and below it; compartmentalized, where there is no relationship between each domain; or hybrid, where both hierarchy and compartments are used. There is no concept of bracketing in mandatory access control design.

questions.question: Ryan would like to implement an access control technology that is likely to both improve security and increase user satisfaction.  Which one of the following technologies meets this requirement?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: All of the controls listed here, if properly implemented, have the potential to improve the organization's security posture.  However, only single sign-on is likely to improve the user experience by eliminating barriers to authentication across multiple systems.  Mandatory access control and multifactor authentication will likely be seen as inconveniences by users, while automated deprovisioning will improve the experience of identity and access management administrators but not affect the end user experience.

questions.question: The leadership at Susan's company has asked her to implement an access control system that can support rule declarations like “Only allow access to salespeople from managed devices on the wireless network between 8 a.m. and 6 p.m.” What type of access control system would be Susan's best choice?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: An attribute-based access control (ABAC) system will allow Susan to specify details about subjects, objects, and access, allowing granular control. Although a rule-based access control system (RBAC) might allow this, the attribute-based access control system can be more specific and thus, is more flexible. Discretionary access control (DAC) would allow object owners to make decisions, and mandatory access controls (MACs) would use classifications; neither of these capabilities was described in the requirements.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of decentralized access control?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: It provides control of access to people closer to the resources.
It provides more granular control of access.

questions.explanation: Decentralized access control empowers people closer to the resources to control access but does not provide consistent control. It does not provide redundancy, since it merely moves control points, the cost of access control depends on its implementation and methods, and granularity can be achieved in both centralized and decentralized models.

questions.question: Which of the following is best described as an access control model that focuses on subjects and identifies the objects that each subject can access?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Capability tables list the privileges assigned to subjects and identify the objects that subjects can access. Access control lists are object-focused rather than subject-focused. Implicit deny is a principle that states that anything that is not explicitly allowed is denied, and a rights management matrix is not an access control model.

questions.question: Susan wants to integrate her website to allow users to use accounts from sites like Google. What technology should she adopt?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: OpenID is a widely supported standard that allows a user to use a single account to log into multiple sites, and Google accounts are frequently used with OpenID.

questions.question: Ben uses a software-based token that changes its code every minute. What type of token is he using?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Synchronous soft tokens, such as Google Authenticator, use a time-based algorithm that generates a constantly changing series of codes. Asynchronous tokens typically require a challenge to be entered on the token to allow it to calculate a response, which the server compares to the response it expects. Smartcards typically present a certificate but may have other token capabilities built in. Static tokens are physical devices that can contain credentials and include smart cards and memory cards.

questions.question: How does single sign-on increase security?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: It decreases the number of accounts required for a subject.
It helps decrease the likelihood that users will write down their passwords.
It provides logging for each system that it is connected to.
It provides better encryption for authentication data.

questions.explanation: Studies consistently show that users are more likely to write down passwords if they have more accounts. Central control of a single account is also easier to shut off if something does go wrong. Simply decreasing the number of accounts required for a subject doesn't increase security by itself, and SSO does not guarantee individual system logging, although it should provide central logging of SSO activity. Since an SSO system was not specified, there is no way of determining whether a given SSO system provides better or worse encryption for authentication data.

questions.question: Which of the following multifactor authentication technologies provides both low management overhead and flexibility?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Software tokens are flexible, with delivery options including mobile applications, SMS, and phone delivery. They have a relatively low administrative overhead, as users can typically self-manage. Biometrics require significant effort to register users and to deploy and maintain infrastructure, and they require hardware at each authentication location. Both types of hardware tokens can require additional overhead for distribution and maintenance, and token failure can cause support challenges.

questions.question: Tom is planning to terminate an employee this afternoon for fraud and expects that the meeting will be somewhat hostile. He is coordinating the meeting with human resources and wants to protect the company against damage. Which one of the following steps is most important to coordinate in time with the termination meeting?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: Informing other employees of the termination

questions.explanation: Electronic access to company resources must be carefully coordinated. An employee who retains access after being terminated may use that access to take retaliatory action. On the other hand, if access is terminated too early, the employee may figure out that he or she is about to be terminated.

questions.question: Jim wants to allow a partner organization's Active Directory forest (B) to access his domain forest's (A)'s resources but doesn't want to allow users in his domain to access B's resources. He also does not want the trust to flow upward through the domain tree as it is formed. What should he do?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: Set up a two-way transitive trust.
Set up a one-way transitive trust.
Set up a one-way nontransitive trust.
Set up a two-way nontransitive trust.

questions.explanation: A trust that allows one forest to access another's resources without the reverse being possible is an example of a one-way trust. Since Jim doesn't want the trust path to flow as the domain tree is formed, this trust has to be nontransitive.

questions.question: The financial services company that Susan works for provides a web portal for its users. When users need to verify their identity, the company uses information from third-party sources to ask questions based on their past credit reports, such as “Which of the following streets did you live on in 2007?” What process is Susan's organization using?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Verifying information that an individual should know about themselves using third-party factual information (a Type 1 authentication factor) is sometimes known as dynamic knowledge-based authentication and is a type of identity proofing. Out-of-band identity proofing would use another means of contacting the user, such as a text message or phone call, and password verification requires a password.

questions.question: Lauren's team of system administrators each deal with hundreds of systems with varying levels of security requirements and find it difficult to handle the multitude of usernames and passwords they each have. What type of solution should she recommend to ensure that passwords are properly handled and that features such as logging and password rotation occur?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Lauren's team would benefit from a credential management system. Credential management systems offer features such as password management, multifactor authentication to retrieve passwords, logging, audit, and password rotation capabilities. A strong password policy would only make maintenance of passwords for many systems a more difficult task if done manually. Single sign-on would help if all of the systems had the same sensitivity levels, but different credentials are normally required for higher-sensitivity systems.

questions.question: What type of trust relationship extends beyond the two domains participating in the trust to one or more of their subdomains?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Transitive trusts go beyond the two domains directly involved in the trust relationship and extend to their subdomains. Nontransitive trusts are not inheritable to other domains. The terms <italic>inheritable trust</italic> and <italic>noninheritable trust</italic> are not normally used.

questions.question: Adam is accessing a standalone file server using a username and password provided to him by the server administrator. Which one of the following entities is guaranteed to have information necessary to complete the authorization process?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: We know that both Adam and the server administrator have the username and password, but this is information used for identification and authentication, not authorization. We do not know what information Adam's supervisor might have. The server is a standalone file server, so it must have information about the activities that Adam is authorized to perform.

questions.question: After 10 years working in her organization, Cassandra is moving into her fourth role, this time as a manager in the accounting department. What issue is likely to show up during an account review if her organization does not have strong account maintenance practices?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Privilege creep is a common problem when employees change roles over time and their privileges and permissions are not properly modified to reflect their new roles. Least privilege issues are a design or implementation problem, and switching roles isn't typically what causes them to occur. Account creep is not a common industry term, and account termination would imply that someone has removed her account instead of switching her to new groups or new roles.

questions.question: Adam recently configured permissions on an NTFS filesystem to describe the access that different users may have to a file by listing each user individually. What did Adam create?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Adam created a list of individual users that may access the file. This is an access control list, which consists of multiple access control entries. It includes the names of users, so it is not role-based, and Adam was able to modify the list, so it is not mandatory access control.

questions.question: Questions like “What is your pet's name?” are examples of what type of identity proofing?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Knowledge-based authentication relies on preset questions such as “What is your pet's name?” and the answers. It can be susceptible to attacks because of the availability of the answers on social media or other sites. Dynamic knowledge-based authentication relies on facts or data that the user already knows that can be used to create questions they can answer on an as-needed basis (for example, a previous address, or a school they attended). Out-of-band identity proofing relies on an alternate channel like a phone call or text message. Finally, Type 3 authentication factors are biometric, or “something you are,” rather than knowledge-based.

questions.question: What access management concept defines what rights or privileges a user has?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Authorization defines what a subject can or can't do. Identification occurs when a subject claims an identity, accountability is provided by the logs and audit trail that track what occurs on a system, and authorization occurs when that identity is validated.

questions.question: Susan has been asked to recommend whether her organization should use a MAC scheme or a DAC scheme. If flexibility and scalability are important requirements for implementing access controls, which scheme should she recommend and why?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: MAC, because it provides greater scalability and flexibility because you can simply add more labels as needed
DAC, because allowing individual administrators to make choices about the objects they control provides scalability and flexibility
MAC, because compartmentalization is well suited to flexibility and adding compartments will allow it to scale well

DAC, because a central decision process allows quick responses and will provide scalability by reducing the number of decisions required and flexibility by moving those decisions to a central authority

questions.explanation: Discretionary access control (DAC) can provide greater scalability by leveraging many administrators, and those administrators can add flexibility by making decisions about access to their objects without fitting into an inflexible mandatory access control (MAC) system. MAC is more secure because of the strong set of controls it provides, but it does not scale as well as DAC and is relatively inflexible in comparison.

questions.question: Which of the following tools is not typically used to verify that a provisioning process was followed in a way that ensures that the organization's security policy is being followed?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: While signature-based detection is used to detect attacks, review of provisioning processes typically involves checking logs, reviewing the audit trail, or performing a manual review of permissions granted during the provisioning process.

questions.question: Joe is the security administrator for an ERP system. He is preparing to create accounts for several new employees. What default access should he give to all of the new employees as he creates the accounts?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The principle of least privilege should guide Joe in this case. He should apply no access permissions by default and then give each user the necessary permissions to perform their job responsibilities. Read-only, editor, and administrator permissions may be necessary for one or more of these users, but those permissions should be assigned based upon business need and not by default.

questions.question: A new customer at a bank that uses fingerprint scanners to authenticate its users is surprised when he scans his fingerprint and is logged in to another customer's account. What type of biometric factor error occurred?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Type 2 errors occur in biometric systems when an invalid subject is incorrectly authenticated as a valid user. In this case, nobody except the actual customer should be validated when fingerprints are scanned. Type 2 errors are also known as false positive errors. Type 1 (or false negative) errors occur when a valid subject is not authenticated; if the existing customer was rejected, it would be a Type 1 error. Registration is the process of adding users, but registration errors and time-of-use, method-of-use errors are not specific biometric authentication terms.

questions.question: Laura is in the process of logging into a system and she just entered her password.  What term best describes this activity?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Entering a password is an act that proves a user's identity and, therefore, is an authentication step.  Laura likely already identified herself by providing her username or performing a similar identification function.  Authorization occurs after authentication when the system determines what actions Laura is allowed to take.  Accounting occurs when the system logs Laura's activity.

questions.question: Kelly is adjusting her organization's password requirements to make them consistent with best practice guidance from NIST. What should she choose as the most appropriate time period for password expiration?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Current best practice guidance from NIST, published in NIST Special Publication 800-63b, suggests that organizations should not impose password expiration requirements on end users.

questions.question: Ben is working on integrating a federated identity management system and needs to exchange authentication and authorization information for browser-based single sign-on. What technology is his best option?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) is the best choice for providing authentication and authorization information, particularly for browser-based SSO. HTML is primarily used for web pages, SPML is used to exchange user information for SSO, and XACML is used for access control policy markup.

questions.question: What access control scheme labels subjects and objects and allows subjects to access objects when the labels match?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Mandatory access control (MAC) applies labels to subjects and objects and allows subjects to access objects when their labels match. Discretionary access control (DAC) is controlled by the owner of objects, rule-based access control applies rules throughout a system, and role-based access control bases rights on roles, which are often handled as groups of users.

questions.question: Mandatory access control is based on what type of model?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Mandatory access control systems are based on a lattice-based model. Lattice-based models use a matrix of classification labels to compartmentalize data. Discretionary access models allow object owners to determine access to the objects they control, role-based access controls are often group-based, and rule-based access controls like firewall ACLs apply rules to all subjects they apply to.

questions.question: Ricky would like to access a remote file server through a VPN connection. He begins this process by connecting to the VPN and attempting to log in. Applying the subject/object model to this request, what is the subject of Ricky's login attempt?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: Files contained on the remote server

questions.explanation: In the subject/object model of access control, the user or process making the request for a resource is the subject of that request. In this example, Ricky is requesting access to the VPN (the object of the request) and is, therefore, the subject.

questions.question: What type of access control is typically used by firewalls?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Firewalls use rule-based access control in their access control lists and apply rules created by administrators to all traffic that passes through them. DAC, or discretionary access control, allows owners to determine who can access objects they control, while task-based access control lists tasks for users. MAC, or mandatory access control, uses classifications to determine access.

questions.question: Gabe is concerned about the security of passwords used as a cornerstone of his organization's information security program. Which one of the following controls would provide the greatest improvement in Gabe's ability to authenticate users?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: Addition of security questions based on personal knowledge

questions.explanation: While all of the listed controls would improve authentication security, most simply strengthen the use of knowledge-based authentication. The best way to improve the authentication process would be to add a factor not based on knowledge through the use of multifactor authentication. This may include the use of biometric controls or token-based authentication.

questions.question: During a review of support incidents, Ben's organization discovered that password changes accounted for more than a quarter of its help desk's cases. Which of the following options would be most likely to decrease that number significantly?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Self-service password reset tools typically have a significant impact on the number of password reset contacts that a help desk has. Two-factor and biometric authentication both add additional complexity and may actually increase the number of contacts. Passphrases can be easier to remember than traditional complex passwords and may decrease calls, but they don't have the same impact that a self-service system does.

questions.question: Jim wants to allow cloud-based applications to act on his behalf to access information from other sites. Which of the following tools can allow that?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: OAuth provides the ability to access resources from another service and would meet Jim's needs. OpenID would allow him to use an account from another service with his application, and Kerberos and LDAP are used more frequently for in-house services.

questions.question: Which one of the following activities is an example of an authorization process?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices

choices.text: User passing a facial recognition check
System consulting an access control list

questions.explanation: Authorization occurs when a system determines whether an authenticated user is permitted to perform an activity, such as by consulting an access control list.  Authentication occurs when a user proves his or her identity to a system, such as by providing a password or completing a facial recognition scan.  When a system logs user activity, this is an example of accounting.

questions.question: Raul is creating a trust relationship between his company and a vendor.  He is implementing the system so that it will allow users from the vendor's organization to access his accounts payable system using the accounts created for them by the vendor.  What type of authentication is Raul implementing?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: This type of authentication, where one domain trusts users from another domain, is called federation.  Federation may involve transitive trusts, where the trusts may be followed through a series of domains, but this scenario only describes the use of two domains.  The scenario only describes use of credentials for a single system and does not describe a multiple-system scenario where single sign-on would be relevant.  There is no requirement described for the use of multifactor authentication, which would require the use of two or more diverse authentication techniques.

questions.question: In Luke's company, users change job positions on a regular basis.  Luke would like the company's access control system to make it easy for administrators to adjust permissions when these changes occur.  Which model of access control is best suited for Luke's needs?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Role-based access control would be an excellent solution for Luke's requirements.  Administrators would assign permissions to roles and then simply adjust the role of a user when he or she changes jobs, rather than changing all of the individual permissions.

questions.question: When you input a user ID and password, you are performing what important identity and access management activity?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: When you input a username and password, you are authenticating yourself by providing a unique identifier and a verification that you are the person who should have that identifier (the password). Authorization is the process of determining what a user is allowed to do. Validation and login both describe elements of what is happening in the process; however, they aren't the most important identity and access management activity.

questions.question: Which of the following is a ticket-based authentication protocol designed to provide secure communication?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Kerberos is an authentication protocol that uses tickets and provides secure communications between the client, key distribution center (KDC), ticket-granting service (TGS), authentication server (AS), and endpoint services. RADIUS does not provide the same level of security by default, SAML is a markup language, and OAuth is designed to allow third-party websites to rely on credentials from other sites like Google or Microsoft.

questions.question: Which of the following Type 3 authenticators is appropriate to use by itself rather than in combination with other biometric factors?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Palm scans compare the vein patterns in the palm to a database to authenticate a user. Vein patterns are unique, and this method is a better single-factor authentication method than voice pattern recognition, hand geometry, and pulse patterns, each of which can be more difficult to uniquely identify between individuals or can be fooled more easily.

questions.question: What type of token-based authentication system uses a challenge/response process in which the challenge must be entered on the token?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Asynchronous tokens use a challenge/response process in which the system sends a challenge and the user responds with a PIN and a calculated response to the challenge. The server performs the same calculations, and if both match, it authenticates the user. Synchronous tokens use a time-based calculation to generate codes. Smart cards are paired with readers and don't need to have challenges entered, and RFID devices are not used for challenge/response tokens.

questions.question: As part of hiring a new employee, Kathleen's identity management team creates a new user object and ensures that the user object is available in the directories and systems where it is needed. What is this process called?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Provisioning includes the creation, maintenance, and removal of user objects from applications, systems, and directories. Registration occurs when users are enrolled in a biometric system; population and authenticator loading are not common industry terms.

questions.question: What access control system lets owners decide who has access to the objects they own?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Discretionary access control gives owners the right to decide who has access to the objects they own. Role-based access control uses administrators to make that decision for roles or groups of people with a role, task-based access control uses lists of tasks for each user, and rule-based access control applies a set of rules to all subjects.

questions.question: When Alex sets the permissions shown in the following image as one of many users on a Linux server, what type of access control model is he leveraging?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The Linux filesystem allows the owners of objects to determine the access rights that subjects have to them. This means that it is a discretionary access control. If the system enforced a role-based access control, Alex wouldn't set the controls; they would be set based on the roles assigned to each subject. A rule-based access control system would apply rules throughout the system, and a mandatory access control system uses classification labels.

questions.question: The U.S. government CAC is an example of what form of Type 2 authentication factor?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: The U.S. government's Common Access Card is a smart card. The U.S. government also issues PIV cards, or personal identity verification cards.

questions.question: What term is used to describe the problem that occurs when users change jobs in an organization but never have the access rights associated with their old jobs removed?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
questions.explanation: Privilege creep is the term used to describe the security issue that arises when users move between jobs in an organization and accumulate privileges that are never revoked when no longer necessary.  This is a violation of the principle of least privilege.

questions.question: Which objects and subjects have a label in a MAC model?
questions.subject: Domain 1:  Security Concepts and Practices
